title: Synthetic Recap
body:
HOUSTON (AP) – In a defensive rock fight that belied the era, one man’s relentless will to score carved out a piece of history. Glenn Robinson, “The Big Dog,” delivered a performance for the ages, pouring in a game-high 44 points to single-handedly drag the Milwaukee Bucks to a grinding 81-76 victory over the Houston Rockets.

On a night where offensive rhythm was a foreign concept, Robinson was a symphony of force. While teammates and opponents alike clanged shots off the iron, he was a study in brutal efficiency. The Rockets, featuring the legendary Hakeem Olajuwon and Clyde Drexler, had no answer. Robinson’s 44 points stood in stark contrast to the game's final score, a testament to his singular dominance in an otherwise stagnant offensive affair.

The rest of the box score reads like a statistical graveyard. Milwaukee’s second-leading scorer, Vin Baker, managed a mere 8 points. For Houston, Olajuwon’s 21 points and 10 rebounds were a hollow effort in the shadow of Robinson’s brilliance. Drexler was held to just 10 points. The teams combined to shoot a frigid percentage from the field, every possession a struggle—except when the ball found No. 13 in a Bucks uniform.

This was not a pretty win; it was a testament to one man’s transcendent talent. On a night defined by missed shots and defensive grit, Glenn Robinson refused to let his team lose, authoring a legendary scoring outburst that will forever be remembered in the annals of franchise history. The final score was 81-76, but this game, in its entirety, belonged to The Big Dog.
